Khazan is a fantastic game that refines the hallmark game mechanics which inspired it. As a “Nioh-like,” it improves upon classic elements like truckloads of gear and smaller, consecutive levels by introducing a cleaner RPG progression and more sensible gear system. It is deep yet easy to understand, it looks fantastic and somehow perfectly renders an animated art style in full 3D. But it also performs exceptionally well, looking good on most settings and delivering reasonably high frames. On higher settings (Very High and above,) 8GB GPUs will encounter VRAM related hitches. Despite this, it is truly a masterclass in the Action RPG and one that deserves far more attention than it currently has. The game is well-worth full price. Ironically, my biggest complaint is that it can deliver a little TOO much time for your money. Before diving in, here’s a few things I think you should know:

-The sheer volume of the game is impressive, however It’s a bit like a 7-course meal; delicious, but simply too much to be savored all at once. I can’t help thinking that my main+extra playthrough could’ve been condensed 10+ hours while enhancing my overall experience.

-If you want to speed things up, realize that side quests are essential for story items but not progression. I expected to grind through side quests as they popped up like Nioh to prepare for the next main mission. 40 hours through yet only halfway through the game, I was getting sick of the grueling pace and decided to knock out main quests in quick succession. I came to discover the sheer disproportion of next-level gear in side quests versus the main story, and found it significantly quickened progression to take on side quests later. If you want to unlock the true ending or simply complete every quest, only go back to optional missions after 3-4 main ones lest you drag out the game unnecessarily.

-You can re-spec, drop in and out of missions to craft new gear, redistribute skill points freely, and have access to several other headache reducers to relieve your struggle. But you cannot switch the difficulty half-way. You can endlessly experiment with your build, but easy or hard mode will stick with you forever. Act accordingly.

In sum, The First Berserker: Khazan it’s well on its way to being the best of the genre. Pacing issues aside, it masters punchy, rhythmic combat. If you like fast and deflection centric combat (almost similar to Jedi: Fallen Order), give this a look.

[h1]Khazan is what happens when Sekiro and Nioh 2 have a child[/h1]

[h2]Overview[/h2]
[b]Khazan: The First Berserker[/b] is a modern action soulslike whatever label you want that takes the best elements from titles like [i]Sekiro[/i] and [i]Nioh 2[/i] and mashes them together into something fast brutal and fun.

If tough games usually scare you off [u]wait[/u] This one might surprise you.

[h2]Quality of Life Things That Just Make Sense[/h2]
[list]
[*][b]You earn XP every time you die to a boss[/b]
Instead of making you grind mindlessly the game rewards your attempts. This small but smart feature keeps you going without the usual burnout.

[*][b]There’s an Easy Mode[/b]
Not everyone has time to git gud. If you’re a working professional short on time or just here to enjoy the combat the easy mode makes the game far more accessible.

[*][b]Boss rematches anytime[/b]
Once you beat a boss you can return to its arena and fight it again. Whether it's to practice or just relive a cool fight it's always there.
[/list]

[h2]The Gameplay[/h2]
Khazan’s gameplay is the standout.

Do you like aggressive fast paced combat
You’ve got it

Do you like tight parries like in Sekiro
That’s here too

Prefer dodging over blocking
Yep the game lets you do that

It borrows a lot from [i]Sekiro’s precision based combat[/i] and [i]Nioh 2’s loot system and yokai style transformations[/i]. If you’ve never played those games don’t worry. Just know that [b]each level is a semi open zone[/b] where you explore fight loot and level up. It’s structured but never dull.

The biggest win [u]It’s the gameplay that keeps you going[/u] even when things get tough.

[h2]The Bosses[/h2]
The bosses in Khazan are [b]peak gaming[/b].

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3484366937

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3476578585

Each one is memorable some are beautifully designed and a few even earn a spot in my all time favorite list. They’re the kind you think about even after the game’s over.

Dragons beasts mages you’ll face all sorts of enemies and they don’t hold back
[i]Some bosses even have their own unique soundtrack[/i] and the visual design alone is enough to make you pause mid fight to admire how good it all looks

They’re tough but fair and every win feels earned.

[h2]The Bad[/h2]
[list]
[*][b]Level design is forgettable[/b]
The stages aren’t as creative or atmospheric as the bosses. Most areas look fine but there’s nothing that really sticks with you once you leave.

[*][b]Boss HP is too high[/b]
Some bosses just drag. Not because they’re hard but because they have way too much HP. It stretches the fights out longer than they need to be and can wear you down.
[/list]

[h2]Graphics & Performance[/h2]
The game [b]looks great and runs smooth[/b]. Stylized visuals with crisp animations optimized really well. Performance isn’t an issue and it’s just plain nice to look at. Every slash and transformation has weight.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
If you love games like [i]Sekiro[/i] [i]Nioh 2[/i] or even [i]Lies of P[/i] then [b]Khazan deserves your attention[/b]

This has become my personal favourite game of this type, ever. Let me explain how:

First and foremost, 

Neople, I will shamefully admit is a development team that I have never heard of until this game came along. And let me tell you, they have done an exceedingly amazing job with this. This South Korean company have made pure gold. Just simply based on playing Khazan, you can tell that they care about the people they made their games for.

Is this a souls-like?

I wouldn't call it a souls-like game however its a perfect blending of both Souls-like and Nioh. To me a Souls-like game is semi open world (still fairly linear) with the freedom to run about and explore, with a central hub area that you can fast travel back to at any given moment. It has the difficulty that will feel both, frustrating and rewarding, it should have the art style of gritty yet beautiful but with fairly simple build crafting and not to mention the amazing bosses. To me, that's where The First Berserker KHAZAN stops being a Souls-like and the similarities with Nioh come into play. The combat in TFBK, feels more fluid, artistic, beautiful. It's fast paced combat mixed with breath-taking combos and visceral flare of blood and violence feels like a beautiful homage to the work Team Ninja did with Nioh. 


What is the combat like? 

As mentioned above the combat within this game is frantic, satisfying and such a rush when you blend your combos together perfectly. You have a choice of 3 weapon types those being, Dual Wield (sword and axe), Greatsword and my personal fav, Spear. Each weapon has their own unique feel to them too, the Greatsword feeling heavy, and cumbersome with bludgeoning brutal attacks. Spear being quick agile and light doing faster attacks but less damage. And the Dual wield being a blend of both previous weapons, slower than the spear but less damage than the greatsword. Each type has their own skill trees (I'll talk about those soon) which give the combat a refreshing take each time you play. The hardcoreness of the fighting and with finisher moves and cinematic camera angles that really capture the brutality of it all makes this games combat truly stand out and makes you WANT to keep coming back for more. 


The skill trees and gear: 

There are 4 skill trees within the game, there being 4 of them, are complex enough yet simple enough to master within moments. You will have the option to build into certain attack skills, reposts, visceral attacks, even perfect dodges. BUT they do create the opportunity to fully go into build crafting ensuring that your personal build could vastly differ from that of someone else simply because of 1 twist. The gear you wear. The gear system in this is not that of a Dark Souls game. As mentioned before it gives a refreshing feeling of Nioh. Your gear here, much like Nioh, allows you to truly build craft. With gear dropping very easily and often, you will spend a while farming enemies for gear to drop or materials require to craft the gear you want. Armour and accessories will have main stats and sub stats, those being, increased stamina or increased health with additional attack, critical attacks etc. Creating a build within this game is not simply, put on strongest gear and leave it alone, as your real damage and build will come from these main/sub stats. 


How are the bosses? 

This game does 2 things perfectly when it comes to the bosses that almost every other game in this genre doesn't do the first? It has the best boss difficulty progression system ever. By this I mean that the next boss you fight will always feel harder than the previous. So knowing that, it prepares you for what's to come with the next boss. And secondly, It allows you to farm bosses. And I mean, farm them. You can kill a boss at the end of the mission, then simply reload the Blade Nexus (bonfire) checkpoint of that boss and simply redo it as many times as you want. As this is how you will earn the materials needed in order to craft certain armour types for your build or for aesthetics. Some bosses will seem repeated through the side quests, however, they will still have new mechanics or feel like they are more in a frantic mode to kill you keeping you on your toes. 


How good are the graphics? 

The graphics in this game honestly can be a miss for some people. Personally I adore them because not only are they a mixture, the character/enemy models are what seems to be cellshaded, but the environments are not in this style at all and mixing the 2 styles is super pleasing on the eyes. Now, I believe as well, which some might not agree with, is the graphics also fit the narrative of the game. By that I mean, the environment doesn't pop out on the screen and the main character/enemies do, it feels like those are your targets, the only things you can see. And killing them, the blood splatter, the hyper stylized gore of it all calms down when the beauty of the background then becomes the focus. Which is what the narrative effectively is. A furious force of revenge and vengeance when needed and serene moments of character building otherwise. 


How good is the story? 

Not a single spoiler or mention of it will I mention other than that which is mentioned above. The story is amazing. 


How good are the voice actors? 

Simple answer? Outstanding. The main standout being that of the main character. General Khazans voice actor - Benn Starr (FF16, Away out, Wukong etc) really stands out in this. Each line is delivered with a heavy tone, mixed with pain, anger, sadness. You can tell what Khazan is thinking and feeling based on the line deliveries. Ben Starr is truly a force to be reckoned with in his field. I can honestly say I fan out now over Ben and his amazing talents. Then with Blade Phantom voiced by Anthony Howell, the gritty, seething hatred that radiates from this performance? *CHEFS KISS* In fact the entire cast, Holly Earl, Alex Brockdorff and others? All out performed and the voices tones, urgencies and softness its unbelievable. 


What's the soundtrack like? 

I beg that you just listen to it. The score for KHAZAN on its own is filled with so much grandeur, sense of power, and a hint of sadness underneath it all. The orchestra, the booming heavy beats of the drums, the sense of empowerment that builds up. Makes you actually FEEL like you can overcome it all. Whatever life throws at you, you will overcome it. I've truly never experienced a soundtrack like this.  The bosses themes as well while feeling electric if you source them out and listen to them alone, are poetic feats of beauty. If you heard them on your own without the game you would still love it. Mix in the gameplay and the feeling of defeating the bosses with that music? Dear god.  


How is the gameplay then? 

Yet again, I can't think of a single flaw. I mean, is there? The game itself feels complete. Polished. Which is rare these days. The game play itself will feel slow and rough at the start, but considering what it is, it does that brilliantly. The late game when you start build crafting, transmog your gear, perfect combining your skills and launching into a full flurry of attacks into a boss, will make you feel unstoppable and have you saying "How the hell did I do that" and you'll be chasing that rush over and over again. You will find yourself invested in finding the collectables, as these will benefit you immensely with different perks, rewards and upgrades. 


Is there a NG+? 

Yes.


Is it worth buying? 

100%. Again the development team at Neople have done a phenomenal job. I truly can't wait to see, buy and experience their next project because with this game being as undeniably perfect as it is? I can't wait to see what they bring to the table next!

review:
The First Berserker: Khazan is a game I initially was interested in for two main reasons:

1. I love a good souls-like game
2. I am familiar with the Dungeon Fighter Universe (I regularly played DFO around 15 or so years ago and really enjoyed it)

Full disclosure, I have not completed the entire game yet, but I absolutely intend to. However, I do believe I have experienced virtually all of the game's core mechanics and I am confident I can speak to them without missing any major components.

So for the sake of my opinion and this review, let's talk about how this game differentiates itself from a Souls-like published by FromSoftware.

Let's be a bit more specific when we say "Souls-like" as far as The First Berserker: Khazan goes. If you have played multiple FromSoftware titles, you know that, although similar, they each have elements that set them apart from each other mechanically. Dark Souls and Elden Ring cover scaling and deep build variety, while Bloodborne focuses more on aggressive gameplay. Sekiro, on the other hand, deals with a very deflection/parry-based combat system, which works very well for it. So where does Neople's game here fall closest to in comparison? Well, I would say it takes elements from all of these aforementioned games in some capacity. It has "brink guarding" which is a great parallel to Sekiro's deflection system, "brink dodging" which is simply leveraging i-frames to avoid damage, and is very rewarding of aggressive onslaught-focused combat, like Bloodborne.

All that being said regarding how it compares to the souls-like genre, there is something that Khazan does exceptionally well that I have not seen much of elsewhere; despite only having three main weapon types (dual wield, spear, and greatsword), the skill tree depth and skill cohesion is phenomenal. There are many skills that can be learned per weapon type that are chainable into or out of other skills, so the game's combat offers a sort of "closed loop" system wherein many available maneuvers synergize with others--this is, in my opinion, what really makes this game's combat shine. You can find so many interesting ways to find new combos using different moves in different orders, or optimizing how you want to dish out that DPS when fighting certain enemies you might have to change tactics for. It's an overall excellent design.

In-combat sound design. When it comes to the importance of timing and reflexes in general in a heated action game like this one, it's crucial that the audio cues and visual information are in lock-step with one another, offering the player unmistakable stimuli that you've either done something right or wrong. You'll be spending a lot of time parrying (brink guarding) and dodging enemy attacks in this game, so I greatly appreciate the developers' commitment to delivering a sound design both satisfying and conducive to understanding the flow of battle as it unfolds in often chaotic fashion that requires the player to really lock in and pay attention to the successes and failures of executing precise maneuvers to hone those critical skills necessary for this game.

The style. The game has a cel-shaded anime inspired style, and it is done extremely well. It brings a lot of color, life, and emotion to the surroundings and environment, so I certainly can appreciate the artistic approach here.

As far as style and atmosphere goes, there is one particular moment I'd like to mention that was extremely memorable for me, which was the Viper boss fight. Everything about that fight was thematically incredible to me. The arena you fight in was an open space, covered with interactive snow that tracked every step and movement during the fight, under a grim sky with a massive moon which cast mysterious, ominous light onto the set. Additionally, in the second phase of the boss fight, upon the boss using a specific move, the arena becomes extremely dark with the only part of the boss visible are the creature's bright yellow reptilian eyes, which struck a menacing, daunting, chord into the fight. Flashes of intense lightning erupted at the exact moments the creature leaped to strike, illuminating the entire arena for brief moments--it almost felt like a movie. And to top it all off, the soundtrack that played added an incredibly tense otherworldly atmosphere, with its choir singing notes of doom and struggle. All of this combined with the on-screen blizzard effects of snow and wind made for, in my opinion, one of the most breathtaking and exciting boss fight experiences I have ever had in a video game. It was truly remarkable and I would hope everyone could experience at least that in this game. Just incredible presentation.

A couple criticisms:
- I have spent much more time than I would like to admit sifting through gear dropped by enemies. You receive gear from defeating enemies extremely frequently, and, as someone who wants to ensure I have the best possible gear equipped as I progress, I found myself spending so much time stopping the action between fights to check out what gear, weapon, or accessory I just picked up to know if it had better rolls or was a higher level than what I currently had on, which disrupted the pacing of the game. Of course, doing what I did is not necessary, but I knew that if I didn't do this, there would eventually be hundreds of items to look at just to get rid of 99% of them, as I would only keep what's optimal. I am aware the game has a dismantling system and upgrading system for these gear pieces which ties into resource management for crafting etc, but I believe the incentive to constantly check what you are picking up from enemies every minute is too prevalent.

- I know I said fantastic things about the combat system and the skill trees, and the synergy exhibited between all those skills for each weapon type (and I still maintain all this!), but I eventually reached a point in which I found myself frequently returning to the skill tree page just to kind of refresh my memory as to which skills I had equipped at the moment. Also, some of the explanations for the skills (exactly what they did or how they triggered) seemed poorly worded, or simply not explained concisely or simply enough. When the game's core mechanics rely so strongly on the player executing these skills cohesively and gracefully, I think it would serve well for the development team to put extra effort into the skills' descriptions to make comprehension extremely clear, and straightforward. I'm not saying it's overly complicated, I just believe it could have been a bit more refined; perhaps a heavier reliance on visual iconography in the skill page would be beneficial.

In conclusion, I have been thoroughly enjoying The First Berserker: Khazan, and will continue to do so as I finish the story, and I also plan to experience the boss rush modes afterwards.

Neople, thank you for this amazing game, and for creating something that has allowed me to recollect and remember some of the things I experienced in Dungeon Fighter Online when I used to regularly play. Encountering the Bard in the Forgotten Temple for the first time and realizing he is strumming his instrument to the tune of the original Dungeon Fighter character select theme was a heartwarming easter egg.

Souls-likes are becoming an over-saturated genre nowadays. With so many games coming out claiming to be inspired by Dark Souls and that particular style of combat it's very difficult to find ones that are actually worth your time.

Some love Nioh 1 and 2. I personally couldn't stand how uncompromising it was.

Some love Lies of P. I enjoyed it for what it was but found to to be fairly uninteresting other than the art style.

Some love Lord's of the Fallen: I haven't tried it but heard it only just became good recently after extensive patches and reworking so I'm nervous to even go near it.

Then out of nowhere from a small time Korean studio comes The First Berserker: Khazan. New kid on the block, with a lot of stiff competition, and that needs to stand out from the crowd in order to succeed. So where does Khazan stand out? Some small positives first: 

There's an actual story that you can watch and comprehend what is going on. A rarity for Souls-likes and good enough to keep your attention and stay invested in. Nothing special but the performances help carry an otherwise average revenge story.

The music is good. Bombastic and gets you hyped up in all the right ways for boss fights.

The art style is fantastic and really keeps same-y environments looking fresh.  The level design is good with a mission structure like Nioh that is just much more convenient and easier to understand at a glance. The actual missions themselves are well structured with enough branching paths to keep things interesting as well.

Build diversity is only just enough. Mainly relying on equipment providing diverse stats and weights to make a build unique. Otherwise you just have 3 styles of main weapons: Dual wielding axe and sword, Big two handed sword and by far my favourite the Spear. Pick one and stick to it. All of this is good enough to feel unique while playing but it can make things feel stale at times in a 40 hour long adventure.

All of this sounds mostly par for the course right? So where does The First Berserker: Khazan truly stand apart for the others?

The Combat and the Boss Design. Seriously. In terms of consistent quality Khazan might actually be the best souls-like and even beat a good chunk of the souls series in general. It's just that good. Parry's, or dodges can all be favoured to your preference with each holding unique advantages and both feel PERFECT. The weapons are completely unique from each other and hold completely different styles of fighting with none truly being "better" but all feeling chunky and brutal. Future combat is opened up with a rage mechanic and some other side systems that really help flesh the combat out.

But those bosses man. On another level. They have spectacle, difficulty and most are completely unique from each other, other than side mission bosses. Some bosses become recurring enemy types but they end up filling the normal enemy roster well, helping you feel stronger and better as you progress through the game. Like i said before though: The quality is just so consistent and most importantly FUN. There are no bad bosses, obtuse mechanics or bulldust moments of frustration....

Just you and the combat. Keep going and keep getting better. Does it get repetitive? Yes it does and that's the games worst fault by far. However the combat is that consistently entertaining that, even after taking breaks to play other games for weeks apart, i could jump back in and enjoy myself just as much as I'd left. It's that intuitive and flows that well.

Khazan delivers a brutal, high paced souls-like experience rooted in fast combat and amazing boss battles. While it can shine in many areas (and boy, does it know how to shine in those), there are also some flaws that should to be talked about.

Pros:
- Combat System: The fighting in this game is absolutely phenomenal. Responsive, stylish and satisfyingly brutal. Each of the three weapon types has it's own skill tree, which enable a deep combo system that encourages aggresive and intense gameplay. Similar to Lies of P, the combat combines best of the both worlds from Sekiro (parry-based combat) and classic Souls, where dodging the enemy's attack plays a vital part. Which approach you should choose heavily depends on the situation, your build and the opponent you are facing at the moment.
- Bosses: The bosses in this game are one of the best in the entire genre, nothing short of spectacular. Each (main-)boss is uniquely designed, hard, but, if you take your time to learn them, never unfair.
- Difficulty: The difficulty is one of the most discussed aspects of this game. On the one hand, there is already literally an easy mode available (which does lock you out of the true ending tho). But still there are mainy claims that this game is too hard when you play it on normal, which is the way it was meant to be played by the developers. Instead of commenting on this with the obligatory "git gud", I'll say this: What is one of the core characteristics of a good Souls-Like? That it is meant to be hard, that you are meant to struggle and (partially) suffer. Only when you failed against a boss, again and again, each time understanding their mechanics a little more, slowly getting the timings right, gradually getting closer and closer to your goal until finally, hands-sweating, heart-pumping, you manage to defeat him - then you have truely beaten, no, mastered the boss and experienced the true meaning and beauty of the souls genre. Push your limits, apply yourself, overcome your weaknesses, git gud. The sense of accomplishment will be worth it.
Armor sets: Armor in this game does not just supply protection against enemies or makes you look like a badass (which it does), it also grants you a variety of set bonuses in the likes of passive buffs, elemental effects or even new skills, which allow for a variety of effective builds and counterplay to certain bosses.    

Cons:
- Level Design: In contrast to most souls-likes, which present a rich, interconnected world to explore (think of Dark Souls, Bloodborne), Khazan opts for a mission-based format (like Nioh). Paired with the for the most part disappointingly linear level layouts, this game fails to create the distinguished dark atmosphere for which especially the Fromsoft games are known for.  
- Story: The plot is your run-of-the-mill revenge story. It's not terrible, but also nothing new or sensational.
- bugs/performance: Two months after release, there are still minor bugs present in the game. Tho the developers are continually releasing new patches, it is still not entirely bug-free, but the main problems have been adressed. What on the other hand really grinds my gears: When did publishers/developers decide, that a game does not anymore have to be polished and optimized regarding performance, and that it is instead just fine to throw a pop up in your face every time you boot up the game, that you should not run this game on an HDD, but on an SSD? Don't out-source the performance problem to me, just polish your games like you are supposed to do (/rant over).  

Khazan may not offer the interconnected, immersive world that other games of this genre deliver and many players crave, but it more than makes up for it through it's incredible combat system and phenomenal bosses. It is punishing but also rewarding and is at it's best when you are locked in in a life-or-death duel with one of it's amazing bosses.

If you live for great boss fights and intense action, Khazan should be your next game.

Anime style Nioh-like with a complex combat system, mission based levels, very well designed and tough bosses but somewhat lacking level design.
[list]
[*]Bosses: the strongest point of the game (along with the combat mechanics). They're very well designed and genuinely challenging (if you get to Viper, don't give up, it will get more manageable after that). The checkpoints are placed right next to the bosses (no more pointless runbacks).

[*]Combat: Perfect dodge, perfect block, reflection (parry with a tight timing), counter attack (against "red" attacks, like Burst Counters in Nioh 2). Humans have white stamina bar, which regenerates quickly, whilst creatures have purple with no regen. Enemies can only be backstabbed from stealth (so no Dark Souls style backstab cheese).

[*]Weapons: there are only 3 weapon types, but each has their own skill tree. Skills can be freely reallocated, which encourages experimenting with different playstyles.

[*]Loot: the game uses Nioh-style (colored) loot. You'll be swimming in loot, which can be overwhelming. Weapons/armor have level and quality, and their stats can be rerolled but no +1 +2.. upgrades like in Dark Souls. There's crafting and set bonuses.

[*]Leveling: you gain little improvements from level-ups, stats will mainly come from your gear and set bonuses instead. Stats can be respecced with consumables.

[*]Performance: despite the UE=bad meme, the game's very well optimized, no stuttering. On an RTX3080, 1440p, Max Settings with DLSS Quality I got around 170 fps, but in some areas it dropped as low as 90.

[*]Game time: 50h to 100%. unless you missed the true ending, in which case you'll have to clear the game again in NG+. Without any spoilers, you can lock yourself out of the true ending by a single dialogue option several missions before the final one. And you can't even back out of this dialogue choice without ALT+F4-ing the game. Also, retroactively setting up the criteria for the true ending does't allow you to redo the dialogue choice, which is silly.

[*]Level Design: the weakest point of the game. Aesthetically nice and there are some interesting levels with good verticality, but overall it's very boring, about on par with Nioh's. Progressing through the levels is generally easy, but it's compensated by the tough bosses. I had no occasions where I would be in desperate need of the next checkpoint.
[/list]

[h1] KHAZAN!!! [/h1]

[b] Pros [/b]
Combat is absolutely peak and feels amazing. Coming from Lords of the Fallen, Khazan felt like an incredible breath of fresh air. Everything plays incredibly fluidly, and the game centers around combo-ing abilities in order to succeed. Khazan very much borrows from Nioh in almost every way, but for me, it meaningfully improves on the formula. Not to mention the skill tree, which is a super nice addition—I love being able to respec for free on the fly. Such a nice quality-of-life feature.

The sound design is some of the best I've heard—everything from the parry clang to the essential enemy audio cues. There are so many rewarding sound moments as you fly around in combat doing insane stuff. This is a good thing, because you’ll be hearing the sound of your weapon repeatedly as you wail on the boss over and over and over again (more on this later).

All the armor choices truly feel impactful and can be crafted to completely change how you play the game (including unique abilities, which is typically poggers). Plus, you can play the fashion game while still rocking your OP set. The way you can hone in attributes and level gear is also very, very welcome and fits well with other aspects of the game where the devs chose to be smart instead of punishing with resource costs. You can very easily beat this game without farming. Finally, there’s a point in the game where mixing and matching feels like a viable option without wrecking your build.

[b] Cons [/b]
Easily the biggest weakness of the game is the story and its characters. It’s very forgettable—unless you’re really into gooning over anime chicks (of which there is no shortage in this game). The plot is extremely tired and drags on way too long with very little reprieve or variety. It's not distractingly bad, but it definitely gets in the way of where the game shines.

This has been mentioned in a number of other reviews, but the bosses are, at times, truly a grueling, unnecessary marathon. This is especially true in the early game, where it feels like your commitment and patience are tested more than your actual “skill” at the game. You're forced to learn every mechanic and niche of the fight and frequently be tested with near-perfect execution. More often than not, it becomes about how long you can stun-lock a boss with combos and attacks; and a run can be completely ruined if your combo breaks. There’s a place for this kind of challenge in the genre, but I’d really warn casual players. Thankfully, this flattens out in the midgame (and most of the lategame) as more combat options open up to you. If you have a full-time job and a kid, Khazan may not be for you.

For a $60 game, only having three weapons at your disposal doesn’t feel quite right. All weapons play very differently, which is awesome, but I would expect more variety right out of the gate—especially when visual models like a giant hammer already exist in the game for brutal attacks, etc.

[b] Mild, totally subjective gripes [/b]
It would be fantastic to get some extended i-frames after a brutal attack. You frequently get punished shortly after killing an enemy, which can be super annoying. I’d even go as far as to say I’d spend a skill point to gain this.

The Bard set is extremely silly and should probably be giga-nerfed. Maybe it shouldn’t have normal stats outside of set bonuses, or it should come with a drawback like taking 25% more damage. The positives WAY outweigh the negatives and let you coast through mobbing while raking in above-average rewards. In my opinion, this trivializes the game and lets you organically get way ahead.

For me, Javelin also contributes to “easy mode” during mobbing. The majority of elite enemies can be dealt with before the fight even starts most of the time. Some of the stuff you can do is cool, but it feels extremely overtuned. Maybe scale back the damage dramatically and make them more of a boss mechanic—like being used to hit weak points for stamina damage, etc.

Delete throwables. Some bosses can literally be killed by throwing one round of each throwable. It’s bizarre to have some fights be so punishing and others be easily dismantled with “free” items. IMO, just give bosses insane resistance to throwables—deleting them might be dramatic :)

I wanted to add a caveat to this review: I used the greatsword for that playthrough. I decided to try a playthrough with the spear, and it's honestly shocking how much easier the game is with the spear. It's far faster, has much more range, and scales with proficiency which means you deal tons more stamina damage, making it much easier to stagger enemies. Like.... I'm breezing through the game. I haven't died more than three times on any boss (just beat the spider), and just once during one of the levels. This tells me that the greatsword really just isn't powerful enough; as slow as it is, it needs to be better balanced to hit harder OR, ideally, it should do massive stamina/stance damage. Anyway.... I still don't recommend the game for anyone but hardcore soulslike fans due to the balance issues and poorly designed late-game bosses. Here's the original review:

---------------------

It breaks my heart to write a negative review of a game I've gotten a lot of joy from, but after 60+ hours and toiling away on a ludicrously overlong and terribly designed final boss, I've just had enough. The payoffs have simply not been worth the hours of frustration and difficulty, especially the bosses.

My soulslike experience is limited: some time in Sekiro, some in Elden Ring, but Lies Of P is one of my all-time favorite games, and I've beaten it five or six times. Recently, I finished Wukong: The Black Myth, but I haven't had much interest in replaying it. But those will be my primary basis for comparison with Khazan. I don't make any claims of being some great gamer, but I'm not one to shy away from a good challenge.

The combat in Khazan, generally, feels excellent. Combos feel impressively devastating, and when you start trivializing enemies it's a great feeling. "Reflect" is absolutely one of the best ideas ever in a game and feels immensely satisfying to use. Khazan gets so much of the moment to moment gameplay just right: the parry system is fantastic — not quite as demanding as Lies Of P, and for the better. Like Wukong, it also has a perfect dodge. And like many soulslikes, you can break your opponent's stance and unleash a high-damage attack with a button prompt.

Here's the deal, and yeah, I'm gonna be that person: this game is too hard. 

Making a game difficult isn't hard or clever; you can just crank up the damage output of enemies, and make them tanks. The real challenge is making difficult boss fights both interesting and rewarding, and Khazan just drops the ball way too many times here, instead just making the bosses tanks that take far too long to kill and deal out far too much damage.

The worst offenders, by far, are bosses like Trokka and the absolutely atrociously bad final boss, Ozma. I will never understand why developers build a whole game around melee combat, then create bosses that literally spend the majority of the fighting running away from you and shooting extremely powerful, fast projectiles. It's not fun, and it's not why I play a game like this. I'll be honest: after struggling for a solid 30 minutes and barely making a dent in Trokka, I knew that I didn't want to spend another 3-4 hours on her as I had Maluca (who was actually a great boss). It's just cheap, overlong, and frustrating. So I turned the difficulty to "easy," and it still took me over a dozen tries. 

"Overlong" is a problem with all of the boss fights. In Lies Of P, the bosses were tough, but the challenge lay in understanding their moves so you could parry them and break their stance to unleash a high-damage attack. Often, when you would finally win, you would absolutely slaughter the boss because you could quickly stagger them. While Khazan has this mechanic, it lacks the reward — the button-prompt combo hardly does any more damage than a regular attack. It feels defeating to meticulously learn a boss's moves, parry the majority of them to whittle away at their stamina bar, but still die because every boss has an absolutely gargantuan health bar and their attacks deal massive damage — often with status effects, too. And don't forget that those bosses who constantly retreat from you also regenerate their stamina, making them extremely difficult to stagger.

Bosses also have a number of vaguely telegraphed AOE attacks and, my least favorite, unblockable grab attacks. These were poorly implemented and horribly overused in Wukong to the game's detriment, and while they're not as bad here (they're better telegraphed and thus don't feel as cheap) they seemingly exist only to frustrate players.

I got so exhausted from every boss — even the ones in side missions — taking 3-4 hours to beat that I just started turning the difficulty to easy for every boss later in the game. They were still plenty hard, with Hizmar taking me several hours to beat despite the reduced difficulty. 

By the end of it, I was just done. The final boss is three phases. Twice, I died on the third phase, meaning that's 20+ minutes down the drain. On easy mode. Toiling away at every boss for hours and hours, memorizing every single move to avoid even the smallest mistake because you are punished hard, against bosses with massive health bars who are immune to throwables and often simply retreat out of range and unleash attacks that are nearly impossible to dodge.... is this fun? Is this why I play video games? 

There's a certain level of frustration that's worth it. Lies Of P pushed me hard that way, but by the end of the first playthrough I couldn't wait to play again. But that's also because for the most part, I liked the bosses in Lies Of P — especially Laxasia and the Nameless Puppet, with their near-constant trading of attacks and parries. But Khazan overplays its hand, and the tanky bosses don't feel like momentous occasions — they feel like an annoyance I want to get past.

The world is, unfortunately, largely drab and uninteresting, with repetitive textures and locations with a bland, desaturated palette. There is some very nice art design later in the game, but the middle portion is full of repetitive caves, dungeons, villages, and castles. I was actually able to follow the story (more than I can say for Wukong), and while it's well-told, the game simply didn't instill that sense of danger and urgency that Lies Of P did, nor was it as touching or evocative.

Khazan had a good run for me. I got several dozen hours of enjoyment out of it, But just as Wukong fell apart in the last chapter with terrible world design and a barrage of egregiously bad bosses, Khazan also devolves into a slugfest where the extreme difficulty doesn't have any payoff. I should feel triumphant when I beat a boss, not relieved that I can get back to the parts of the game I was enjoying. The last boss is so badly designed, so utterly unenjoyable, tedious, cheap, and overlong, that even on easy it was no longer worth the effort. Could I farm for legendary gear and keep trying? Could I just be persistent and beat him eventually? Could I watch a bunch of videos with tricks and tips to beat him? Sure, but why go through all that trouble for a boss fight I don't enjoy at all?  I mean really, if I haven't conveyed enough how much I dislike this boss, I uninstalled the game because I genuinely have no interest in repeating such an atrociously, insultingly bad boss fight.

So despite my positive early impressions and some brilliant mechanics, I think Khazan ultimately falters under the weight of trying out-hardcore other soulslikes. And, just for the record, a friend of mine also purchased Khazan, and unlike me he is a diehard fan of the genre. He's beaten every Fromsoft game and most of the soulslikes. He quit Khazan because of the difficulty.

DAMN. This game blew me away. I went in expecting awesome combat and a one-note story, but to my surprise I was *invested*. What starts out as a bloodbath revenge tale starts to unravel into multiple plots that involve relationships, loss, tragedy, and the arcane.

Khazan is an awesome main character. He starts out as like the badass doom-guy who just wants to murder every living thing that wronged him, but as you do the side missions you start to learn he was a truly good guy, a respected leader and a caring friend. He is also very to the point and no nonsense which makes him even cooler. The voice actor did an amazing job too, he suits him perfectly!

Besides the story, man the combat in this game is insanely cool and so much fun. If I had to summarise it, it really does feel like a Doom Eternal soulslike. I played the great sword exclusively throughout the whole story and it was sick. You get so many cool skills that at first just feel like flashy damage moves but end up being strategic as you get more comfortable with your weapon. Not to mention the brutal/execution attacks, MAN. I swear I saw like at least 20 unique animations of Khazan ripping different enemies in half. The sound design of this game enhances it even further by making every kill, every clash of metal, and every step so satisfying. Especially all the parrying and greatsword clanking sounds.

The level design was always smart and fun to navigate, but I think the highlight of this game is the bosses. These bosses are some of the most incredible I've seen in video games ever. They were amazing set-pieces, with brutally difficult (but super-fun by the end) patterns, some with jaw-dropping backing tracks. I'm getting chills just thinking about some of the last few songs!!

I think if you like souls games, you can't miss this one. Especially if you're one of those freaks that fetishizes difficulty, this game will beat the shit out of you.

Definitely revisiting for a NG+ run with trying out the other two weapons!

review: Combat makes you feel like an overpowered anime character. Its so awesome.

Pretty much straightforward in its gameplay loop, where combat is everything, but anything else is reduced to a minimum or is laughably bad. The main problem of Khazan is that it doesn’t have its own vision - just a basic fantasy setting with goblins, spiders, skeletons, and a pinch of a revenge plot in the background. You can clearly see how all of the resources went into the combat system, which resulted in a brutal-ish spectacle where every blow is accompanied by a dopamine-inducing impact. It’s very hard to complain from a gameplay perspective because it works - and it fucks.

Trust me, you will like it - especially knowing that it focuses only on 3 types of weapons, with a decent amount of skills, combos, and buffs for each type. And you can reset skills anytime you want! And yes, it’s not a Soulslike - more like a Nioh-like, where fights require precision and aggression towards foes.

That doesn’t mean you can’t take a defensive approach by applying parry for every attack. Yeah, it has parries - [i]"One of the worst mechanics in recent years"[/i] or something like that. Hate it or like it, but it’s the main basis of the game, and I have good news for you: there are two types of parries, but you can basically dodge everything if you’re not a fan of defensive playstyles. So you can either use only dodging or combine a little bit of everything to succeed against the hardest aspect of the game - bosses.

I don’t want to say that they’re hard - pretty much passable and fair - where the originality comes from the fight itself [i](unfortunately, not from the design of them)[/i]. On normal difficulty, the only problem for me was the amount of HP they had, which leads to the longevity of the battle. Still, bosses are the highlight of the game - except for mages and their [i]"let me fly away for a few minutes so I can spam you with shitless amounts of projectiles."[/i]

I would say Khazan feels like a boss rush game with a massive amount of filler represented by the levels themselves, where you’ll pray to get another battle so you can forget for a second that there’s a shallow catacomb level on your way. Not the middest game I’ve played - pretty cool, especially the bosses. But I don’t think I’ll play it again in the near future.

[h1]The First Berserker: Khazan — A Brutal, Unforgettable Challenge[/h1]
From the start, I appreciated that Khazan doesn’t lock me into a single playstyle. Whether [b]parrying, dodging, or guarding[/b], I could adapt my combat approach depending on the fight.

I’ve played Souls games [b]a lot[/b], so I expected a challenge—but Khazan pushes things even further, demanding [b]precision, aggression, and endurance[/b].

[h2]Combat: Fluid, Adaptive, and Brutal[/h2]
Combat in Khazan is [b]one of the best I’ve played[/b], but its [b]mechanical balancing struggles in late-game fights[/b]. [b]Brink Guard (parry)[/b] is tight, rewarding precise timing, but stamina depletion and HP scaling issues hold the experience back.

I relied on [b]dual wield and spear[/b], with spear becoming my go-to for its [b]speed, range, and ability to extend Moonlight uptime[/b]. [b]Moonlight activation requires landing three consecutive Swift Attacks[/b], but if I was interrupted, I had to [b]restart the sequence entirely[/b] before I could chain into [b]Assault or Reversal[/b]. Even when I successfully executed the combo, [b]stamina drained too quickly[/b], making fights against [b]status-inflicting mobs (Poison, Flame, Chaos)[/b] particularly punishing.

Late-game enemy HP [b]bloated so much that fights became exhausting endurance tests[/b], forcing players into prolonged encounters that felt more about survival than skill. The [b]weapon kits for dual wield, spear, and greatsword need adjustments[/b]—for instance, the execution speed of [b]greatsword attacks[/b] is [b]too rigid[/b], locking players into [b]predictable sequences[/b] that struggle in high-pressure battles.

To counterbalance this, the [b]upkeep for chained maneuvers needs reworking[/b], allowing [b]Moonlight extensions to flow into Assault/Reversal, then into additional multi-hit skills[/b], creating [b]a more consistent offensive rhythm[/b] rather than forcing constant resets. However, even if players successfully execute these chains, [b]stamina drains far too quickly[/b], limiting engagement and further amplifying the difficulty gap against enemies with [b]excessive HP scaling[/b].

A [b]reduction in stamina depletion[/b], paired with [b]improved chaining of multi-hit attacks[/b], would help [b]shift combat toward mastery rather than endurance[/b], ensuring weapon abilities feel [b]responsive, rewarding, and competitive against high-health foes[/b]. Without these adjustments, fights continue to feel [b]drawn-out and imbalanced[/b], requiring excessive effort for limited payoff.

Using [b]greatsword[/b], I often felt like I was [b]backseating the fight[/b], holding a defensive stance and [b]waiting for an opportunity to strike instead of actively engaging[/b]. This was especially noticeable against [b]quick-attacking enemies like Viper[/b], whose relentless speed [b]forced me into a reactionary role[/b], struggling to find clean openings. The [b]slower execution of greatsword attacks[/b] meant [b]enemies interrupted me before I could land a decisive hit[/b], turning encounters into [b]drawn-out battles of attrition rather than rewarding duels[/b]. Instead of feeling empowered, I was [b]waiting for my turn[/b], which [b]broke the momentum[/b] of combat.

[h2]Bosses: Ozma Sets the Bar, Others Lag Behind[/h2]
There’s no debate—[b]Ozma is the best boss fight I’ve ever played[/b].

His [b]multi-phase battle constantly forced me to adapt[/b]. [b]Missile barrages[/b] kept me moving, explosions cutting off escape routes, while his [b]relentless slashes and lunges demanded perfect Brink Guard timing[/b]. [b]Sweeping combos baited dodges[/b], making counters crucial. Unlike many late-game encounters that relied on [b]high HP to stretch out difficulty[/b], [b]Ozma’s challenge came entirely from his mechanics[/b], making the fight thrilling instead of exhausting.

Other bosses didn’t reach this level. [b]Too many relied on status effects instead of innovative attack sequences[/b], and [b]delayed attacks became frustrating rather than rewarding[/b]. The [b]bloated HP pools[/b] dragged out encounters, replacing strategy with endurance grinding.

[h2]World & Art Direction: Stunning Aesthetics, Flawed Design[/h2]
Exploring Khazan wasn’t always engaging. [b]Stormpass and Mount Heinmach lacked atmosphere[/b], feeling [b]more like obstacles than immersive locations[/b]. The [b]early game is repetitive[/b], improving later but never fully delivering.

Enemy placement frustrated me. [b]Archers behind elites, exploding spiders, and relentless gank squads[/b] turned encounters into frustrating battles rather than skillful duels. This issue was [b]clear right from the tutorial[/b], where the game [b]introduces archers/shooters placed behind mobs[/b], foreshadowing the [b]artificial difficulty padding seen throughout[/b].

That said, the [b]art direction is phenomenal[/b]. [b]Cel-shaded character designs against realistic backgrounds create a unique, visually striking look[/b]. [b]Bruises and cuts stay on enemies as I fight them[/b], adding a brutal touch that enhances the sense of impact in every battle.

Once again, this game proves that [b]art style matters more than chasing realism[/b]. Korean developers have been [b]putting out incredible titles[/b], with Lies of P, Sanabi, and Dave the Diver all pushing distinct aesthetics. Khazan follows that trend beautifully.

[h2]Loot & Progression: Unbalanced and Lacking Basic QoL Features[/h2]
Crafting [b]wasn’t worth the effort[/b]. [b]Loot drops constantly outclassed crafted gear[/b], making upgrading [b]pointless minutes after grinding materials[/b]. The [b]Diablo-style loot mechanics[/b] clashed with Khazan’s Soulslike systems, making build progression [b]feel more dependent on random drops than planning[/b].

On top of this, the [b]inventory management system needs a serious overhaul[/b]. [b]Sorting weapons and armor by set would make comparing stats much easier[/b]—right now, flipping between helmets, chest pieces, and attributes feels clunky. Being able to [b]view all equipment from the same set side by side[/b] would help with making meaningful loadout decisions rather than constantly jumping between individual items.

[h2]Story: Functional, But Forgettable[/h2]
The story wasn’t bad, but it [b]lacked depth[/b]. I hoped for something layered, like Elden Ring, where [b]lore unfolds naturally through exploration[/b]. Instead, Khazan [b]relies on straightforward cutscenes[/b], making the narrative feel [b]surface-level rather than immersive[/b].

[h2]Final Verdict: Combat Excellence Held Back by Flaws[/h2]
Despite its issues, Khazan [b]kept me hooked[/b], especially in the fights that delivered.

[b]Ozma’s battle alone makes this game worth playing[/b], setting a new standard for what a Soulslike boss should be. The [b]combat system is exhilarating[/b], rewarding fast reactions and perfect execution. But [b]bloated enemy HP, stamina depletion issues, repetitive level design, frustrating enemy placements, and an unbalanced loot system[/b] prevent Khazan from reaching true greatness.

This game [b]punishes mistakes and demands endurance—but when it clicks, it’s an absolute thrill[/b].

[b]Final Score: 8.5/10[/b]

* High skill ceiling (eg, Reflection) but accessible to all (eg, Guard/Dodge and Brink Guard/Dodge)

It's not an easy game by any stretch of the imagination, but I never felt like it was unfair.

Like I said, it isn't perfect, so if I could change a few things, it would be this:

* Some of the bosses are a little spongy.
* Inventory management could use a little more work, which I think is already planned.  Specifically, we need to be able to sort by armor set, and I'd also like to see things like throwables on their own tab.
* The Phantom Form mechanic sucks as it is currently implemented, as do the Phantom "Abilities".  They need to merge the two together, drop the passive effect (everyone just uses Keshta), and make the Phantom Form a special move that changes depending on what Phantom you have selected.
* The skill trees should have dedicated points for each weapon instead of being a global pool.  Get rid of the Common tree altogether.
* Finally, the five primary stats need to be reworked so they work with all weapons instead of the current funky weapon scaling that means you should respec each time you change weapons.

A better way to do would be:

Vitality - Increases health
Endurance - Increases stamina
Strength - Increases weapon damage and carry weight
Willpower - Reduces damage taken
Proficiency - Increases damage done with javelin/throwables

This would allow people to tailor their builds to their play style and freely swap between the weapons without having to redo their skill tree every time and stats every time.  After you progress to a certain point in the game, you basically have unlimited respecs, so there's no point in making it just a tedious chore.

Having said all that, I had a total blast in the game, and I am absolutely looking forward to the next game these developers come up with.

review: This game is an absolute masterpiece if combat centred games are your main interest. It has literally everything a souls-like fan could ask of, you've got layered armour so that you wouldn't sacrifice your looks for better stats, 3 types of parries, mikiri counters, sidestep dodges, a skill tree that features unique skills for each weapon class, follow-up skills so that you can perform numerous combos and keep extending the punish window, decent and serviceable story (this will appeal to you if you enjoy a good revenge tale), and a devil-trigger-like transform which makes fights even cooler. I can't even begin to express how much I liked the boss designs in this game, I always looked forward to the next boss even though they were extremely challenging. However, I NEVER felt like they were unfair, just difficult. This game takes inspiration from almost every single popular souls-like game out there and improves upon those features even more to offer you a vastly improved final product. Despite initially experiencing a bug where the netherworld energy orb I picked up disappeared from my inventory, they still gave me a whole bunch of useful collectibles and consumables at the end of my playthrough which I really appreciated, I still think the game is an absolute masterpiece. 10/10

review:
This game ticked every Soulslike box I look for.

Boss fights are genuinely epic. They're tough but not unfair. It never feels hard just for the sake of being hard. There’s always a way through — whether that’s learning to dodge, guard, or reflect properly. Every encounter teaches you something, and that’s the kind of difficulty I respect.

Combat is where Khazan really shines. You get three main weapon styles, each with their own flavor. Every style has multiple skill branches that you can explore — or completely ignore — depending on how you want to play. It’s flexible and encourages experimentation. Whether you're into calculated strikes or chaotic brawling, the game supports it.

If you play it like a Dark Souls game — dodge, run in, poke, run out — you're going to get wrecked. Khazan rewards relentless aggression. You’re expected to stay close and keep the pressure on, even more so than Sekiro or Black Myth Wukong. It’s fast, intense, and honestly pretty addicting once it clicks. Go Berserk, ika-nga. 

Level design is solid for a linear game. Nothing groundbreaking, but it serves the experience well. The lore is on the generic side, but still adds enough intrigue to keep you interested. Crafting and the weapon system are decent — there’s room for improvement, but it’s functional and satisfying for the most part.

My only real complaint is the inventory system. It’s messy, the sorting options are terrible, and it becomes a pain once you start collecting more items. Definitely needs a quality-of-life update.

If you're into Soulslikes and want something fresh that still respects the core of what makes the genre great, Khazan is absolutely worth your time.

review:
Where to start with this title?

First off: Have you played and enjoyed Nioh 2 at all? If so, buy this game. This is not a joke or an exaggeration. If you enjoyed Nioh 2 I can just about guarantee you will have fun with this title.

If you have not played Nioh 2 before, this game is a souls-like, but it would probably be more accurate to call it a boss rush with souls-like elements. The game is level-based rather than an inter-connected world, and there is plenty of exploration and loot to find. However, there are only three types of weapons, with the moveset of all weapons of the same type being exactly the same. IE: all spears have the same moveset, all greatswords have the same moveset, and all dual-wield sets have the same moveset.

The emphasis here is on the combat, and mastering your choice of individual weapons. And combat feels *good*. Really good. This game emphasizes aggressive play, and forcing openings in your opponents. After all, you are the first "berserker" Khazan. Nowhere is this more prevalent than when you reach the end of a level and find the boss. Every main boss in the game has a varied moveset that will punish you for sloppy play and/or passive play. These moveset are fun to learn, and even more fun to conquer. Especially the last few main bosses that really amp up the scale.

There is a massive emphasis on perfect blocking and perfect dodging to avoid damage while keeping on the offensive pressure, so a level of precision and reaction is required, not dissimilar to Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice.

The story is promising, but unfortunately doesn't have enough buildup for most of its key moments. So it's not selling the game. However, the combat is so good, and the moment to moment gameplay so fun, I don't actually care that the story feels slightly underwhelming at points. If you like the sound of a boss rush game with fast-paced nioh style gameplay, there is nothing better than Khazan. 

If any of that sounds remotely interesting to you, at least give the demo a shot. It's free, and has you playing through roughly the first 2 hours of the game. Any progress from the demo carries over into the full game. If the demo piques your interest when playing through it, you'll likely have a good time

First Berserker: Khazan surprised me in the best way possible. It’s a tight, focused action RPG that knows exactly what it wants to be—and delivers it with confidence.

The gameplay is simple to pick up but leaves plenty of room to master. From your first swing, the combat feels weighty and impactful.

The game immediately lets you try every weapon type, which I loved. It gave me a real chance to find a style that clicked—and it made early-game experimentation fun, not frustrating.

Exploration is heavily rewarded. The map is filled with secrets, upgrades, and collectibles that make your character stronger. You’re constantly encouraged to venture off the beaten path, and the game respects your time by making it worth it.

Boss battles are the highlight. Each one is unique and challenging, with distinct mechanics and memorable designs. They’re tough, but never unfair—and beating them feels incredibly satisfying.

The art direction is striking. The environments, enemy designs, and overall atmosphere feel dark, gritty, and beautifully executed.

The campaign isn’t too long, but it doesn’t feel short either. I had nearly 90% of the collectibles before finishing the final boss, and I immediately wanted to dive into New Game+.

That said, a few things could be better:

Fast travel could use improvement. Currently, you have to return to the main hub to use the Blade Nexus, which breaks up the pacing a bit too often.

The main hub itself is a bit fragmented. Important vendors like the jar seller, nomad, your follower, and the blacksmith are all in different areas—requiring load screens just to hop between them. It’s a small thing, but it adds up over time.

Still, those issues didn’t stop me from loving the game.

Combat is crisp, progression feels meaningful, and the world pulls you in. Each time I downed a boss, I felt that real rush of accomplishment that only the best soulslikes deliver.

If you're a fan of action RPGs or challenging games in general, First Berserker: Khazan is absolutely worth your time.

I think there is kind of a triangle when it comes to souls genre.
Dark Souls - Sekiro - Nioh

This game is towards the Nioh side. But, the combat is near identical to Lies of P, almost copy and paste but with Nioh type combos and flashiness. It's very buttery and well made. 

This game is most similar to Nioh in the level design, but with Lies of P boss design. It also has the loot style of Nioh - shit loot everywhere. 

You know how Dark Souls games usually reward exploration with really unique loot? Well this game rewards exploration heavily, it's everywhere, but, with mostly shit loot or crafting materials. I say shit loot but realistically it's useful consumables or crafting materials to them make into better gear, but it's doesn't feel good. It's quantity over quality. Almost every enemy drops some scraps, every corner has a piece of loot, and after a few hours, I just stopped looking at what I picked up because it was unimportant to me 95% of the time. You take all the loot, go through the mess and mark the ones you want to keep and then scrap or sell everything else.

You do however use this loot for what this game does well, which are the gear builds. There is a decent variety of builds you can make, you can slightly mix and match, but in my experience there were only 2 clear strong gear sets out of the 10-12 options I had for the weapon I chose. I used 1 set of gear for 95% of my playthrough.

The game left a really bad impression on me towards the end. Every level got longer and longer and longer, making the boss fights further apart. The levels are so uninteresting and while the mobs are well made, it gets old when you fight the same ones for 20+ hours and you just want to get to the next boss fight. Also, the levels are extremely easy. I probably died 50 times during the entire playthrough, and only maybe 5 of these deaths were not against boss fights.

And then the last level and the final boss. Awful.

The last level was frustrating because I just basically conquered the game, Im making the final push to fight the final boss. But the level was just like any other bland level, except it had a long gotcha platforming section that is designed to prank you and kill you. I'm not saying it was difficult, but when I have only died like twice during a normal level, and then I die 3 times to pranks in a platforming section at the LAST level, it's like, why was THIS your finale? Why is THIS level my test of skill or my epic buildup to the final boss? It felt like the game wanted to create artificial difficulty.

And then the final boss. Not hard, just not engaging, literally. He runs the entire fight and shoots projectiles at you. In a game ENTIRELY about parrying and combos, the final test of skill is an enemy that runs away and throws projectiles the entire time? The fight took me around 20-30 minutes because you spend the majority of the fight waiting for him to land on the ground so you can hit him. It was by far THE worst designed boss in the game. Most of the bosses were very well made though. But man the last level and last boss were just such big let downs.

The game is well made overall, everything works smoothly. But, the ONLY single thing this game does better than other souls likes, is the build crafting. Which isn't even that great, just good.

A [meh] souls-like, besides having a similar combat style and bonfires, there's nothing else that makes this souls-like a souls-like. Re-skin, reuse and repetition are the biggest and most evident issues of the game.

The story is mediocre, and the OST is not noticeable and, unfortunately, forgettable.

[h3] The biggest issue is exploration. [/h3] 

There are no zones or regions; it's just "missions", which are short levels with a hard start and a hard end with a boss, no matter what. There's nothing connecting missions with each other; just drop in, get to the end, kill the boss, repeat. On top of that, the level design and visuals were mediocre.

Once you complete a mission, you will likely get a side-mission or 2 or sometimes even 3 on that "level". But those optional missions are "re-skined" main missions, you get spawned at a "sliced" map of the original missions with the exact layout but some paths are blocked and monsters are of different type along (some adjustments to environment to fit the mobs and minor changes to environment, but the re-used parts are so evident it became obnoxious).

These "isolated" levels diminished the feeling of exploration to almost nothing, but it is itemization that made it a complete nothing.

There were some collectibles besides the "estus flask" updates that gave you minor power creep, but nothing special, just an item lying around; something to look out for.

[h3] Reusing bosses and maps is the second biggest issue [/h3] 

All of the optional bosses were just either downscaled main bosses, or exact same boss with a different skin, or just a mob with a larger HP pool. This made the optional missions just dogsh*t in my opinion. Before you even started, you already knew that you won't see anything new or cool on that level.

Some side missions were different, but 95% of them followed the same formula and offered nothing but items, soulstones, and jins to make yourself stronger for main missions.

What was nice was having a bonfire just before the boss, + dying left your "souls" at the entrance, and you even gave you extra "souls" for trying and failing the boss to giving you a chance to catch up with a recommended level. 

[h3] Itemization is the third biggest issue [/h3]

Having attributes and sets is nice., However, they matter too late into the game. 
Once you've picked your set, the attributes and rarity were nice to fiddle with, but it doesn't come in until after 20h. In the early game, the attributes and levels barely matter. In my opinion it is a poor design to make a game system that is good for late game(+30h), but it fails to captivate anyone in early-mid game.

It is the Item Levels that made me not care about items after around 5h. Your inventory becomes a mess of random bullsh*t; same items but different levels. Picking items became a "oh cool a "helm of whateverthefuck" lvl 10, whatever, I'll see it 20 more times". 

[h3] Early game is actually okay [/h3]

Before you notice the above issues, the game is decent.

Combat is "arcady" compared to typical souls-likes, but that's not bad, it was kind of fun. It's not that serious, so you mostly just do combos, dodges/guards/parries, and mess around with mobs and bosses. However, once you've unlocked all the skills (around 20h) there's nothing new to be done; you just do what works and deals the most damage on repeat, nothing changes at that point, especially with bosses.

What was really good was the freedom to experiment. The attributes were easy to switch, and most importantly, the skills were free to respec at any point. This allowed to to spec into any of the weapons and set at any point and time, and doing so made the game fun for the first hours, until the other issues became more evident.

* Kbm accessibility is the best I've seen in any souls-like and especially better than anything from Fromsoft.

* Changing abilities is available from the start and free to do. 
* Changing stats is also fairly easy. Eventually you can craft the item and the materials are obtained naturally. I can probably craft 1k of this item at this point. 
* The game has plenty of enemy variation. I don't know why people would say otherwise.... maybe the hard stuck players who've only seen a handful of different types. 
* Combat has a quick pace and brink guarding and dodging feel responsive. 
* Each of the three weapon types have their own unique set of challenges and styles. (No, great-sword is not the hardest weapon to play). I've played through the game 5 times. NG (dual-wield), NG+ (spear), NG++ (great-sword), NG (spear), NG (great-sword). * Bug-fixes. Every new launch, especially now days, has bugs. This game had it's fair share, but nothing game breaking. The developers have been rolling out patches to fix various issues.

Cons:
* Only three weapon types. I suspect they'll introduce more, but that is the current state as of the time of this review.

First Berserker Khazan would be a forgettable run-of-the-mill Souls-like BUT its combat feel more like Hack N' Slash that it singlehandedly carries the game. This feels like a blend of Sekiro, Lies of P, and especially Nioh, with a heavy emphasis on parrying, unlocking perks, and way too much loot.

I’m generally not a huge fan of skill trees but Khazan kept giving me great skills to unlock all the way to the end. This holds the real build potential where you can craft your own playstyle. You can remove skills with no punishment which lets you make every point count. They only have 3 weapons. Many won’t like the smaller roster but like Bloodborne, lower quantity means higher quality. All 3 are fun, unique, and have an insane amount of depth. I did Spears on my first run and tried out Greatsword on the mean time which were both incredibly fun and distinct. Tough bossfights but fair, and if you died at the boss room your souls respawn outside the boss room like Lies of P and you gain souls from bosses even if you lose, which are easy. This also has a summon system similar to Lies of P. It’s an ai, no multiplayer, but there’s one outside every boss door and you can fight phantoms to level up yours. I didn’t use this system but it seems like a great way to make the game more manageable.

If you're a big anime fan like myself, you will love the story. It's not overly compelling, but it made me genuinely care about some characters to the point where I felt strong emotions towards the end of the storyline. This could be partly due to the wonderful cinematics and soundtracks, especially during certain boss fights.

Overall, i would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys Action RPGs; it certainly delivers everything you'd expect from the genre and introduces some refreshing new mechanics.

review:
Incredible combat and not much else. 
This game knows exactly what it wants to be - a kickass action game with souls like elements - and never tries to be anything more than that. And that's perfectly fine for me!

Very satisfying game, amazing visuals, amazing combat/gameplay, unreal cut scenes, good soundtrack, good boss roster, insane combo potential, optimized and art style which is very anime (cell shaded). Without a doubt the best souls-like (if it classifies as one). Things I didn't like - this has a lack enemy variety (endgame mainly) and has reskin bosses that have slightly different movesets which were not fun to fight even though I had fought them already. The enemy placements were questionable, especially towards the halfway point and onward, there's parts where strong enemies are put in a small area with an archer at the back picking me off (for example) and the level design is on the weaker end, finally the story is very barebones, follows the classic revenge plot with minor plot twists. In terms of difficulty, it is fairly balanced, personally, i didn't struggle too hard although i struggled on 3 bosses; [spoiler]Viper, Maluca, Ozma[/spoiler] , there's a lot of things in your disposal which makes fighting them pretty forgiving. Also, you're telling me its possible to launch a game that is well optimized and almost bug free right out of the gate in the year 2025!? I ran the game on a 3060ti, high settings preset, and capped at 75 FPS which ran buttery smooth (1440p). There was the occasional stutters here and there but they weren't too bad, props to the devs for releasing a game that guarantees a smooth experience. I think this game is worth your time, there's even a demo (about 2 hours long) which instantly hooked me in. Length of game is perfect, I did all side missions and achievements which clocks in at 61 hours to beat. All in all, 9/10, Great learning experience, forgiving gameplay and difficulty options too. What more can you ask for, strongly recommend.

After almost 30 hours, I really can't bring myself to finish nor recommend this game. It's really a shame because The First Berserker: Khazan's deflection mechanic is about as good as Sekiro's. That's truly saying something considering how a lot of other developers tried to do the same with their games, but didn't quite hit the mark. I tried Lies of P for about 6 hours on Xbox and stopped because deflection felt awful. I played through Stellar Blade and have one play through left to get 100%; it did deflection better than Lies of P, but there was still a bit of delay even with the equipment that improves on it. Khazan, however, managed to nail the kind of precision needed to have a deflection mechanic that worked well against fast combos.

[h2]So, why don't I recommend it despite liking the core combat mechanic it's built around?[/h2]
Somewhere along development, Neople forgot that they still needed to have a fun game in between boss fights. A lot of moment to moment gameplay fell flat.

[h3]Level Design[/h3]
Level design was far too simple and uninspired. One of the favorite "shortcut" methods I noticed in the game was to make you fight a difficult or "Elite" enemy not long after a "bonfire" and after you defeat it, there's immediately a "shortcut."

[h3]Player Attack Feedback[/h3]
Hitting enemies with the greatsword doesn't have a satisfying feedback. For one, too many regular non "elite" enemies are able to shrug off greatsword swings. You have to charge up or combo into a second swing to get any kind of hit stun on your attacks. An extremely slow initial swing that doesn't have any oomph is terrible for such a heavy weapon. The sound weapons make when hitting bodies is so dull and underwhelming. It just doesn't feel good, but I'm a stubborn greatsword user so I stuck with it. I'm not sure if the other two weapon types are any better, but I'm too tired of this game to try them out.
The way combat plays out against regular enemies in Khazan feels too much like Neople didn't want the player to ever feel strong.

[h3]Intrusive Particle Effect Lighting[/h3]
A lot of special attacks the player can do often creates these red slashing particles behind the weapon and I found myself having difficulty seeing smaller enemies at point blank range because of them. Part of that, though, is probably because of Khazan's body also obstructing player view and smaller enemies don't have enough visual indicators to compensate for the perspective and the effects flashing. A good example of this is Elamein. She has a few attacks that were difficult to follow when Khazan is at point-blank range. It's funny because it's this exact reason why FromSoftware protagonists are often manlets. Larger enemies are easier to see; go figure.

[h3]Uninteresting Plot and Characters[/h3]
It's pretty self explanatory. I wouldn't complain about it if the non-boss fight gameplay was more satisfying, but it isn't. So, I try to find entertainment elsewhere. It's not in the story, characters, or dialogue, that's for sure.

[h3]Minor Complaint[/h3]
Boss Attack Animations
Additionally, bosses often have the weird delayed swings people complained about in Elden Ring. This one is more of a minor nitpick since, despite the annoying attack delays, I was able to buckle down and learn the fights I did well enough to the point that the tries where I do beat them almost seem like a perfectionist run. Though, I still bring it up because I wish developers wouldn't follow FromSoft on this kind of attack animations; I found them ugly in Elden Ring and I find them ugly in any other game that does them. Even for a video game, the movements look far too unnatural. Learning boss fights in Sekiro felt like a dance while learning them in Khazan felt like being offered a high five and getting kicked in between the legs instead.

The First Berserker: Khazan is really not a bad game. The deflections are smooth and precisely tuned. Learning the boss fights are often very stimulating and it's gratifying to see patience payoff as I figure out the right moments to unleash damaging skills, but there are a lot of things in the moment to moment gameplay in between boss fights that could use some tweaks to make them feel more fleshed out.
