Here is my review after finishing The First Berserker Khazan (100% in 2 playthroughs):

The game left me with a mix of exhilaration and frustration, on one hand the combat is like nothing I have experienced before, 37 uniquely crafted bosses, each with its own arena and behavior, deliver some of the most memorable encounters I’ve ever had in a souls like game.

On the other hand, the story and characters never rise beyond background noise. The game has multiple endings, yet none of them left an emotional mark. Traversing the gorgeously hand painted levels is a joy, but the vengeance arc lacks weight, making the long playthrough feel unevenly rewarded.


Progression & Replay
Progression is entirely linear. You unlock up to Epic gear in the first run, with Epic gear being abundant at the end of the game. In NG+ you start to encounter Legendary gear toward the end, and in NG++ Legendary gear becomes more attainable. NG+ also opens up powerful new skill tree branches especially status effect mitigation that make later runs feel noticeably smoother (I only died four times in my second clear). However, the demo weapon you get early on has intentionally superior B+ scaling, and no main game loot ever matches it, granting a built in advantage that few weapons can rival.


Difficulty & Player Agency:
Khazan teaches you every mechanic up front perfect blocks, parries, dodges, consumables and then forces you to use them in lockstep. Even flawless guards build status effects (poison, burn, shock), so you can’t turtle your way through. You must dodge some telegraphed strikes, drain status with NG+ skills, and lean on every tool in your arsenal. Veteran Souls players will appreciate the fair but punishing curve deaths feel earned but if you love minimalist or unconventional builds, expect to be punished hard even in NG+.


Crafting & Customization
You can craft many unique, stylish armour/weapon/accessory sets, level up equipment by sacrificing higher level fodder, and craft status resistance armour sets, but the loops can grow grindy. Transmog is locked until NG+, which is a needless cosmetic gate. Once you hit the end game, crafting feels like busywork rather than a fun optimisation puzzle.


Visuals, Audio & Tech
Hand painted, manga inspired arenas and fluid, expressive animations make every fight legible and dramatic. The orchestral score swells perfectly for gauntlets, while crunchy FX on successful parries deliver visceral feedback. I did not encounter any lag or performance issues during my playthroughs.

The First Berserker Khazan Pros & Cons:
Pros
* 37 memorable boss encounters
* Precise, weighty combat and parry system
* Strong art direction and technically solid performance

Cons
* Bare-bones narrative and forgettable lore
* Linear, unvarying progression
* Rigid build requirements punish unconventional play styles

Sins
* Demo weapon imbalance: Early demo gear sports B+ scaling that no main-game drop can match, unbalancing progression by design.
* Cosmetics locked behind NG+: Transmog remain unavailable until New Game+, frustrating players who want to customize from the outset.



Bottom Line
If you’re craving a fresh souls like game with relentless boss gauntlets, Khazan delivers in spades. But if you crave build freedom, memorable storytelling, or randomised exploration, you’ll feel its constraints.

I fucking hate this game. It's a really odd scenario for me where the game started off REALLY well but the farther into the game I get, the more I see this game to fall into the "prepare to die" meme where bosses and enemy placement are purely designed to kill you at all costs.

***TL;DR AT THE BOTTOM***

However, let's get into the review. For reference:
Linux Mint 21.3 Cinnamon
7900XTX
64GB Ram
13th Gen i9
Proton GE 9-25


### Audio

I played the game half in Chinese dubs and half in Japanese dubs. I have no problems with either. Likewise, this game is HEAVY. What I mean is, when I swing my giant slab of a weapon and hit an enemy, it's very audible. When the giant goat demon smacks me with a pickup truck he calls a weapon, I FEEL that shit. I love how heavy and weighty things are in this game.

Likewise, the ambiance and atmosphere are spot on. I have no complaints about the audio in Khazan.


### Graphics

Khazan has its own artstyle and it's pretty nice. Khazan, the protag, is very visually distinguished in just about every way. Other characters are cleanly defined and the artstyle shines through. Enemies are also cleanly defined.

I did not notice any texture warping, bending, graphical bugs, etc. I have no complaints about the graphics in Khazan.


### Linux Performance

The game basically ran right out of the box. I originally started on Proton Experimental (bleeding edge) but later had some problems after an update. Switching to GE 9-25 solved the problems. Aside from that, it was a smooth 60fps (capped) experience the entire time. Wish more games were this effortless.


### Gameplay

So this is a soulslike with Diablo style loot, sorta like Nioh but not that autistic. You have a light attack and a heavy attack. You can block, parry, and dodge. This game does have a stamina bar which I'm not too fond of anymore but it's not a bad thing. I'm not going to get too deep into this because it plays just like most other soulslikes.

As for loot, it can drop in various rarities with various affixes on them. It seems most equipment, aside from accessories, belong to a set. Set bonuses can be a pretty big deal. For example, draining an enemy's "stamina" puts them into a stagger state where you can wail on them for a bit and also execute what's effectively a visceral attack. Viscerals come in two flavors whether it'll kill the enemy or just damage them. I must say, the killing viscerals are brutal and I love it. One of the earlier sets offers a skill that, once per stagger, will reset the stagger window and give you even more unobstructed damage. Love it.

Aside from that, this game also features aerial AoE takedowns. Similar to something like Ronin, if you're elevated above an unaware enemy, you can do an aerial visceral that also has a small AoE impact to it. This is, as you might imagine, also very brutal and I love it. Khazan is a brutal guy and the game conveys that well.

Lastly, similar to Nioh, you can dismantle gear you don't want and craft gear you do want. To craft gear, you need the blueprint for it which is often found around the levels. I didn't feel that these were very hidden but I'm also the kind of person who tries to explore everything so YMMV.


### My Gripes

## Enemy Placement

I'm a big fan of Dark Souls 2. I feel like it's the only game in the trilogy, with the exception of the first, that tried to be a sequel. However, Dark Souls 2 is often criticized for a lot of things like "the spambush" and "peppering you with archers".
Why do I bring this up? Khazan does both of these in the most egregious manner. Almost every enemy encounter that isn't a solo experience is riddled with archers. So you either dodge arrows you don't even see coming while dealing with the melees or sprint past them to take out the 3+ archers scattered around the arena. 
Khazan also has an egregious amount of spambushes. I mean, it's *sorta* fine because I used a greatsword and it has very wide swing arcs but I can't imagine how it'd be for a spear main. Still, the cancer of archers and the prominence of spambushes makes me feel like this game just wants me dead at all costs and I find that to be a bad thing.


## Boss HP, Movesets, and Phases

This is a really weird topic for me because I feel like boss design got progressively worse as the game went on. The dragonkin boss in the snowy area? Absolute cinema. Vergil knockoff? Absolute cancer.

There some weird quirks in these boss fights. It feels like every damn boss, with the exception of a small handful, have some kind of ailment associated with them. I get it - goat demon has a fire nail and it'll burn me if it touches me. But... why do I still get flame buildup WHEN BLOCKING? Is my greatsword alive and an extension of myself? My weapon is pretty stamina heavy and I did not skip out on investing in stamina and HP alongside my damage stat but... it's just a lot of damage. To make matters worse, at that point in the game, there is no shop to buy ailment recovery items or a way to make them. So, if you run out, you're screwed.

Likewise, later bosses just have... way too much HP. Combine that with the multiple phases that damn near every boss has and it just feels like a slog. I just crafted, what I can assume to be, the highest iLvl weapon I possibly could and it feels like I'm tickling bosses unless I'm hitting them with a fully charged heavy attacks. In addition to the bloated HP and multiple phases, these bosses do shitloads of damage with Elden Ring-tier attack chains. Again, it feels like the game wants me dead at all costs.

Lastly, movesets are all over the place. I had a hard time when I got to the first real boss - the dragonkin guy in the snowy area. However, learning his moveset felt rewarding to finally beat him. Vergil knockoff later in the game? I couldn't give a shit less. I felt like I just got done smacking myself in the nuts when the fight was over. I was elated. Not because I surmounted a challenge but because I don't have to deal with that shit anymore.


### What I DID Like

## Equipment Crafting

No one wants to farm Lothric Knights for 2 hours until the one item you want drops. However, this doesn't work in the classic Souls experience since there are no affixes or rarity.

## The Weight of Gameplay

I like how heavy, brutal, and visceral Khazan is. Khazan is a berserker, usually identified with sheer, overwhelming force. I FEEL that when I do a visceral or even swing my sword. I REALLY like how they nailed this aspect and this is probably the one game I'll think about when I think of a Greatsword done right. I loved watching mooks smack me with twigs while I poise through it, charging my delete key.

## Aesthetics

The armor/weapon designs in this game are pretty fucking cool. The Soul Eater set is my favorite and I appreciate the way Khazan takes his helmet off for cutscenes. He's a goddamn berserker, he doesn't need a bitch-mask.

## Mission Checkpoints

One of the things that made farming Nioh levels a chore is having to run from the start to the actual point you want to get to. Wo Long does that shit too. Khazan? Checkpoints are unlocked as you find them and you can freely travel from the hub to any unlocked checkpoint. FUCKING. BRILLIANT. Team Ninja - take notes.


### Overall Thoughts/tl;dr

I played the demo and it seemed pretty neat. Bought the full game and fell in love as soon as I picked up the greatsword. Game started off really, really well and just seemed to nosedive from there. Bloated boss HP, cancer 15-swing combos, all the goddamn archers and spambushes all over the place really ruined the experience. I haven't even finished this game but I don't think I even have the willpower to.

Maybe this game, like Sekiro, just "isn't for me" and that's fine. However, I've experienced what I see are problems and I'm not going to just overlook those.

The fact that you have armor sets is also very akin to Nioh, also "Phantom mode" being basically Niohs "Living Weapon"/"Yokai Shift" form, and even most of the keybinds being the same Nioh uses, but most annoyingly it has collectables that are just as, if not more annoying than in Nioh.

Granted, Khazan does some things better than Nioh, like less trash equipment bloating your inventory, and sets being a whole lot less annoying to craft, because you don't have to grind bosses for the smithing text or the item itself to randomly drop in Nioh.
Instead you can just beat old bosses rather quickly to get the material, or even buy a limited number of them, to craft them, at your current level.
And the materials even specify from which levels boss they drop, if you even need boss materials to craft that set.
You can find most recipes by exploring, which i believe can potentially be easy to miss, if you don't take the time to explore levels, while some recipes are "hidden" behind rewards from killing some of the special enemies in a certain way (which in itself i think is also a cool reward system).

[h3]What it does badly[/h3]
In my opinion the collectables, aka Soulstones and Jarlings (and Khazans Memories*), are jarring.
Especially because Jarlings are tied to player power, by allowing you to buy head pieces that give extra stats while not taking up set slots, and Soulstones making your healing stronger (cause i didn't care for the Lacrima) and increasing your max spirit.
There were also some grievances that i had with backtracking explained further down.

*
(I don't have too much of an opinion on the Khazan Memories, because i always managed to find them without going back, but i could see people being annoyed by having to backtrack for them too, since they were also sometimes hidden behind breakable/illusary walls, and also tied to player power.)

[h3]How collectables affect exploration[/h3]
I felt the need to have a guide open at all times when going through levels, because missing them was extremely annoying, since once i beat the boss, i had to run through portions of the level again.
And sometimes running through the level got very Jarring, because on my way there i had to kill pretty much all the enemies, because of how far they would chase me, unlock elevators again (which are also made so you can't access them during combat, so they actively discourage from speeding through levels again), find the one hidden illusary/breakable wall that i missed, just to get to where i needed to go.
Just seeing levels with 5 Soulstones and a Jarling (i was about to write Kodama, cause they are basically the same thing), made me groan in my head, because i knew i had to go through the level more carefully, to not miss these random walls again.

I have nothing against backtracking, but it's annoying when you have places you can't backtrack to, or when its unnecessarily tedious.
There are very few instances of that happening, but it was annoying whenever it did happen.
One example i have is in "First Act of Revenge" where i chose the last Blade Nexus to teleport to, after having already finished the level.
I was blocked from backtracking downhill, because of a boulder, that is supposed to roll down, as you normally enter the area from other side, allowing you to go uphill.
But because he boulder "reset" and neither you nor the enemies could kick it down, i was basically "locked" in the later portion of the level.
Another example is in the same level, where it has nothing to do with the level resetting, but after you go past the boar and jump down, you can't get back up.
And then, even if you reach the next Blade Nexus, you first have to teleport back to The Crevice, rather than being able to just teleport to an earlier Blade Nexus, from another Blade Nexus.
Every time you have to teleport back to The Crevice, making you sit through an extra loading screen, and then you go back and select the Blade Nexus you want.

I was more excited to play through the side missions, simply because they were shorter and usually easy to backtrack, and because they only had 0-2 Soulstones, so even if i missed one, i can run back quickly and search for it.
I felt the same way about Nioh and the Kodama, but at some point i felt they're not very impactful, so while it was annoying to not have collected all in a level, i just kept going and never repeated these 5-8 Kodama levels again (plus Nioh levels don't let you teleport to any checkpoints, only the start of the level.
Honestly, i believe if these things were implemented differently, exploration and backtracking would feel alot better.

I loved how some Soulstones were hidden in the environment for example,where i just had to chuck a spear at them.
That also made me look around more and into the distance, and appreciate the environmental design, but the "hidden" ones, in some close quarter areas, are just so easy to miss, and they made me feel like i have to look at every wall.
And yes, at some point i realized that the Jarling jars always have a little "effect" on them, so they can be spotted more easily, but these collectables just made me feel like i had to pay attention to every single jar, the ground, and every wall. Constantly.
To me, that does not feel great, and it soured my experience, of how i felt i had to traverse the levels, to not re-explore these levels, rather than actually "exploring" levels more freely.

[h3]Another tiny negative [/h3]
One other small gripe i had was 2-3 specific bosses spending alot of time out of your reach very frequently. [spoiler] Princess Ilyna, Reese and especially Ozma [/spoiler]
While on 2 of them it felt alright most of the time and not as drawn out, it felt really annoying on 3rd one mentioned in spoilers, especially with the amount of attacks that boss inflicts status on you with and the amount of phases the boss has, making it an extremely drawn out fight.

[h3]Closing thoughts[/h3]
If the devs were to reduce the tediousness of backtracking and if they made breakable/illusary walls a little more prominent if they wanna have that many of them in their game, then i'd be a bit more excited if they were to announce a DLC or a sequel.
But as of now, all i can say is that i enjoyed it a bit more than my recent playthrough of Nioh 2, but i believe that's mainly due to Khazan being a shorter game with less side missions overall, making it less bloating

Having dumped thousands of hours into DFO over nearly 15 years, as well as being an avid fan of Souls games, this game was a no-brainer for me. While Khazan is technically a "souls-like" game, it's closer, spiritually, to Nioh, which is known more for it's mission select level design rather than being a more open world style. I would say that Nioh, and by extension Khazan, is very different from a classic Souls game, and I would keep that in mind if you're looking to try Khazan out. If you didn't really enjoy Nioh much, Khazan does share a lot with it. However if you, like me, enjoyed Nioh, then you will LOVE Khazan.

As an added bonus, if you're a fan of DFO, or even if you've played DNF Duel, you'll most likely find Khazan interesting in some way from a lore perspective. It was exciting seeing certain characters from DFO, a sprite game, come to life in a big 3D action RPG, and finding references to DFO in Khazan's world design was extremely fun for me as a long-time fan.

The main allure to Khazan is it's combat. The combat feels fluid, responsive, visceral, and hefty. All three weapon types have distinct playstyles, but each feels exceptionally rewarding to learn and master. Leveling up and gaining new skills feels exciting and rewarding, plus being able to freely switch which weapon skills you want to use encourages the player to experiment and try new things when met with resistance. I found myself using all three weapons throughout my first playthrough. Additionally, being able to dodge, block, and parry enemies felt extremely satisfying, since you're encouraged to use every defensive option in your arsenal. If dodging doesn't work out, try blocking. If blocking doesn't work, try dodging. The game of trial, error, failure, success, and ultimate triumph is exemplified in Khazan's combat variety.

Boss difficulty would bounce between "fair" and "cheap" depending on the boss, but by the end of the game I definitely had fun fighting most of the game's boss offerings. However, none of the bosses felt particularly simple, and each of them had interesting quirks that kept me on my toes. Personally, I'd rather a boss have a cheap gimmick than fall over without a fight. Bosses feature a lot of HP, which ensures that you spend a good amount of time fighting each one. I never felt like a boss fight ended too soon or was too easy, but I did find that certain boss fights dragged on a touch too long sometimes.

I think if I had to pick a bad point about Khazan, it's level design and visuals. The game's visuals are good, but the environments lack contrast, especially early on. It feels like there's a constant haze in front your eyes that makes the world look dull. While I do understand that it works from an emotional standpoint, Khazan's point of view is bleak and it's meant to look dreary, from a gameplay standpoint it makes levels look a bit uninteresting to look at. On top of that, certain enemy encounters drain almost all color from the screen, sending you into a nearly greyscale world.

Enemy placement felt oddly predictable, I didn't really feel challenged by the normal enemies very often. I could generally understand what kind of encounters I would face based on the appearance of the level. Getting ambushed around a corner or being shot at by archers on a bridge, seeing a broken piece of dock by the water with a conveniently placed item next to it. A lot of these types of scenarios are ones I've seen done previously in other games, and didn't feel very original. Despite that, it's not a huge deal to me, especially in a game like this where boss fights are the big focus, I can forgive a slightly boring level layout.

All in all, Khazan is a satisfying game that I will certainly play more of even after beating it once. Definitely give it a shot!

I'll give it its props. Khazan is a good little soulslite that really excels in combat and boss fights while being largely lackluster everywhere else. Nioh meets Sekiro, but not quite as good as either. It's not as fast or as complex as Nioh. It doesn't quite have the great level design or enemy variety of Sekiro either. Khazan doesn't necessarily do anything new. It's familiar territory, but given how often developers screw up the basics, it's nice to see a title that executes it well for the most part. That said, the game features many of the same weaknesses as Nioh. Terrible camera, repetitive linear levels with samey enemies, optional bosses being literal copies of main bosses, a completely forgettable plot, and boring random loot. The art style is decent. The armor designs look really cool and bosses are an impressive spectacle. I like the cel shading used here. Environments are a little less inspired. A lot of brown and gray caves and dungeons that got so damn old to navigate. Bosses are a huge highlight but Lord have mercy do they take forever to die. You basically die in like 3-4 hits, but they need a Killer Instinct Ultra combo just to get staggered. Nioh was like this as well, but combat was much faster and thanks to the Ki Pulse mechanic you could unleash combos without ever needing to wait for stamina to regen. Waiting for stamina to regen is so common in boss fights here. It just kills momentum. This game also has a hyperdemon mode like Nioh except it's pure trash. Slow weak attacks and a low duration. Why would I waste a dozen skill points on a spirit mode that can't even do as much damage as Khazan in his normal form? Build variety is quite light given the small shallow skill trees and only three weapon types. Several stats just become dump stats once you find a weapon you like, so progression becomes boring. Not really much of an RPG. I enjoyed my time with Khazan, but I got bored of the overlong bland levels and really just wanted to get to the next boss fight ASAP. I didn't enjoy any of the side missions which are mostly just the same bosses you fought previously. Good, but unexceptional. Should hold you over 'til Nioh 3 descends from the heavens. (7/10)

Writing this review as the credits roll after my first NG on dual-wield, amazing game, I can say one of the best souls-likes I've ever played. At first it was hell, having to understand and use all of the game mechanics, and realising that you can't get much far using only deflects, parrying and counterstrikes are a must. Once you get a feel of the combat, it feels even more satisfying than Devil May Cry/God of War or other classic slashers. 

The game is advertised as a souls-like, although it is an absolute rhythm game. What I found really cool, is that the game forces you to understand every boss pattern before you can kill it, which means if you will leave boss at 10% hp, lose your mind and all in, you will find yourself next to a last bonfire. Keep your mind cold, use consumables and wear great fashion. (You can also wear one set of armor by stats, and another by style, which I found really cool). People are complaining about level design, but I enjoyed exploring every location, main or dungeons, even though some felt simpler than others)

Bosses are outstanding, there are some reuses, but only in dungeons, and most of them are lore-explained. As mentioned above, each one requires unique approach and understanding the pattern really makes you feel rewarded. 

A lot of QoL like fast respawns, bonfires near boss rooms, and no-button dead souls collection.

If you enjoyed Sekiro, this one is for you. Looking forward new updates and wishing you all the best in development.
